frameDefinitions: Some entity (Theme) starts out in one place (Source) and ends up in some other place (Goal), having covered some space between the two (Path).
This frame contains words for motions or actions an Agent performs using some part of his/her body.
The words in this frame describe the manipulation of an Entity by an Agent.
An Agent creates a Knot (possibly in a Place and/or with an Instrument).'
An Agent causes a Theme to move from a Source, along a Path, to a Goal.
This frame concerns the movement of a Theme and an Agent and/or Carrier.
frameExamples: That kite you see just to the right of his head was <t>moving</t> around pretty fast but the camera seemed to catch it ok.
Loretta <t>ties</t> the most beautiful bowline I've ever seen.
She <t>threw</t> her shoes into the dryer .
Karl <t>carried</t> the books across campus to the library on his head.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Theme</fen> is the entity that changes location. Note that it is not necessarily a self-mover.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the location the <fen>Theme</fen> occupies initially before its change of location.
The <fen>Path</fen> refers to (a part of) the ground over which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels  or to a landmark by which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is the location the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up in.
<fen>Area</fen> identifies the setting in which the <fen>Theme</fen>'s movement takes place without a specified <fen>Path</fen>.
<fen>Distance</fen> is any expression which characterizes the extent of the Motion.

This role is used for expressions that indicate motion along a line from the deitic center towards a reference point (which may be implicit) that is neither the <fen>Goal</fen> of the posture change nor a landmark along the way of the moving part of the body.  Often <fen>Direction</fen> is defined with reference to the canonical orientation of the Protagonist, or the orientation imposed by an implicit observer.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the Motion occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the general area in which a specific motion (with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, or <fen>Goal</fen>) occurs.
The <fen>Agent</fen> uses some part of his/her body to perform the action. <fen>Agent</fen> occurs as the External Argument.
With some verbs in this frame, the <fen>Body_part</fen> involved in the action is specified by the meaning of the verb and cannot be expressed separately.  For example,
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the body movement occurs.
The location within which the movement of a <fen>Body_part</fen> takes place.

The <fen>Agent</fen> manipulates an object. <fen>Agent</fen> typically refers to animate beings, but is also extended to mechanical and other inanimate objects.  <fen>Agent</fen> is most frequently expressed as the external argument of verbs:
The <fen>Entity</fen> being manipulated often occurs as the direct object of verbs:

The part of the <fen>Agent</fen>'s body being used to manipulate the <fen>Entity</fen> may also be expressed. While the default is for an <fen>Agent</fen> to use his/her hands, other body parts may be specified. This frame element usually occurs as a PP-complement.
When the manipulation takes place
The spatial setting in which the manipulation takes place.
The Agent is the person performing the intentional act.
The stable configuration of a String which results from tying.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the one whose action causes the motion of a <fen>Theme</fen>.  The <fen>Agent</fen> is generally realized as the External Argument.
The role <fen>Theme</fen> is generally an NP Object.
The role <fen>Source</fen> is the starting point of motion.
The role <fen>Path</fen> is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor <fen>Goal</fen>.
The role <fen>Goal</fen> is the point at which the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

The role <fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular or not to consist of a single, linear path. Locative setting adjuncts may also be assigned this frame element.
<fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, typically non-human, force that causes the <fen>Theme</fen> to be set in motion.
A resultant state that the <fen>Theme</fen> is in at the end of its motion.
A previous state that the <fen>Theme</fen> was in before the beginning of its motion.
The time at which the motion of the <fen>Theme</fen> occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the general area that provides a setting for a specific motion (with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, or <fen>Goal</fen>).
The <fen>Agent</fen> is a sentient being who physically controls the movement of the <fen>Theme</fen> via the carrier, accompanying the <fen>Theme</fen>.
<fen>Goal</fen> identifies the endpoint of the path.
<fen>Source</fen> indicates the beginning of the path along which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels.
Path along which carrying occurs.
The objects being carried.
<fen>Area</fen> is used for descriprion of a general area in which the carrying action takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular or not to consist of a single, linear path.
The <fen>Carrier</fen> provides support for the <fen>Theme</fen>.  Movement of the <fen>Carrier</fen> results in movement of the <fen>Theme</fen>.
The time in which the carrying event takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the general area that serves as a setting for the specific motion of the <fen>Agent</fen> and <fen>Theme</fen> (with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, or <fen>Goal</fen>).
listRoleExamples: The explosion made <fex>me</fex> move in a hurry.
The policeman moved <fex>away from the door</fex>.
Jo moved <fex>past Dad</fex> into the hall.
The car moved <fex>into the slow lane</fex>.
Emily moved restlessly <fex>around the room</fex>.
The twig floated atop the water <fex>for about 100 yards</fex>.
A radioactive cloud drifted across Britain <fex>after the fire at the Windscale nuclear factory</fex>.
<fex>The boy</fex> swung his legs.
Pat yawned (*his mouth).
There was singing for joy in the streets, and <fex>everywhere</fex> people lifting their arms into the air.
<fex>A robot arm</fex> grasps the box on the conveyor belt and seals it.
Squeeze <fex>the ball</fex> as many times as you can.
Kim grasped the needle <fex>between finger and thumb</fex>.
I seized the letter <fex>before he did</fex>.
<fex>In the hallway</fex> he managed to grabthe monarch by the ankles
<fex>Pat</fex> threw the china at the wall.
Pat threw <fex>the china</fex> at the wall.
Pat dragged the box <fex>out of the cupboard</fex>.
I pushed the trolley <fex>along the street</fex>.
Kim threw the cat <fex>into the garden</fex>.
Kim pushed the lawnmower <fex>around the garden</fex>.
<fex>The storm</fex> tossed the sailor from the boat
The fireman dragged the injured driver <fex>clear</fex>
Paul pulled Fran upright <fex>from her sitting position</fex>.
We shoved half of the cargo overboard <fex>on the 29th</fex>.
<fex>Karl</fex> carried the books across the campus to the library.
Karl carried the books <fex>to the library</fex>.
Karl hauled the books <fex>from the library</fex>  to the office.
Karl carried the books <fex>across the campus</fex>.
Karl toted <fex>the books</fex> to the car.
<fex>The boat</fex> ferried the troops across the river.
<fex>Even in such a small port</fex>, these boats would transport many tons of trade-goods in to shore annually.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: The By a Waterfall number in Footlight Parade
